question: Let <katex>$A=\{a,b,c\}$</katex>, then the number of equivalence relations on A containing (b, c) is
explanation: Smallest equivalence relation containing (b,c) must contain (c,b) and diagonals: <katex>$R_1 = \{(a,a), (b,b), (c,c), (b,c), (c,b)\}$</katex>.
Any other relation must involve 'a'. If we add (a,b), we must add (b,a), (a,c), (c,a) due to transitivity with (b,c). This leads to <katex>$A \times A$</katex>.
So there are exactly 2 equivalence relations.
